column1: huge difference, for example, between playing a game like "Quake" and listening to a radio broadcast that tells you that your family will be killed unless you take action to kill others now. [SEP] The latter is the kind of media propaganda that was used to unleash a genocide in Rwanda in 1994, which killed 800,000 people. [SEP] Similarly, the main motivation for the crusades (beyond the promise of wealth) was that Christians were supposedly being slaughtered and had to be saved. [SEP] Obviously, media propaganda can incite people to kill. [SEP] Interactive fiction like video games, on the other hand, presents violence in a narrative context, which may very well desensitize participants to said violence, but no causative link has ever been proven. [SEP] Moore's hypothesis (which apparently
column3: at least in part from the book "Culture of Fear" by Barry Glassner, also advertised on Moore's website) is that the constant bombardment with messages of fear can incite paranoia, which itself can lead to violent acts. [SEP] This is consistent with the kind of media-incited violence described above, and in no relationship whatsoever to the theory of video game or music incited violence. [SEP] It is no surprise, however, that US (and European) media do not question their own propaganda of fear. [SEP] Moore's second hypothesis is that America's foreign policy may contribute to the belief that violence is an appropriate means to solve conflicts, a hypothesis which is shared by many sociologists and psychologists. [SEP] Children who grow up in war-torn regions are known for having similar views

column1: ver attribute to malice what can be attributed to incompetence. [SEP] The somewhat inept editing of the NRA press release has led some viewers to wrong conclusions, which is unfortunate, but Moore's critics have no interest in viewing the matter fairly. column1: Conclusion You write: "Bowling for Columbine is dishonest. It is fraudulent. To trash Heston, it even uses the audio/video editor to assemble a Heston speech that Heston did not give, and sequences images and carefully highlighted text to spin the viewer's mind to a wrong conclusion." [SEP] None of this is true. [SEP] What is true is that Bowling for Columbine is a diamond in the small world of big screen documentaries, one that shines brightly and illuminates an often misunderstood aspect of American culture. [SEP] It is not a flawless diamond -- the "48 hours" scene in particular suffers from bad editing, the statistics are suboptimal, and Heston gets a bit more bashing than he deserves. [SEP] Other than towards the NRA, the movie tries hard to avoid simplistic conclusions, and
column3: up with some thoughtful answers. [SEP] The most shameful part of the ongoing attacks against Moore is that these answers have been all but ignored by his critics. [SEP] Had Moore wanted to make a propaganda film, he would have used other material: photos from America's Emergency Rooms. [SEP] Certainly, Moore is one of the most talented filmmakers in the United States today, and his film fully deserved its Oscar. [SEP] The shrill (and remarkably unsuccessful) Internet campaign to "revoke" his award seems to be motivated more by jealousy than by real concerns about the film's accuracy. [SEP] It is not only the highest grossing non-music documentary of all time, among the users of the largest Internet film database, IMDB, it is also the highest rated one. column1: The Rediscovery of Language and Identity Humans, in the process of defining themselves, look to immediately recognizable factors in order to differentiate themselves from others. [SEP] This process leads to the development of what can be broadly termed culture: a group of people joined by characteristics, traits, and beliefs
column3: to view themselves as sharing a distinct identity, discernible from that of those “outside” them, those who do not belong. [SEP] Naturally this can be signaled by any number of things - clothing, food, lifestyle choices. [SEP] One of the most dominant and easily noted factors is language. [SEP] The command of a language, while not affording guaranteed access to the community which speaks it, is often the key to gaining entry. [SEP] In turn communal identity can be formed around a language; it is used as the focal point around which the group gathers. [SEP] Therefore when considering the indigenous revitalization movements which began in 20th century Latin America, the impact of those indigenous languages on those movements and the nature of the identity of the peoples themselves is key. Now leave, before I call the rats on you.” [SEP] We left. [SEP] Nepthys shook his hands at me like he wanted to wrap them around my neck. [SEP] “You idiot,” he hissed, “do you know how much you’ve set us back? I should say, set yourself back, since it’s your girlfriend we’re looking for.” [SEP] I thought about Rachel; in the excitement, I had forgotten why we were chasing down vampire experts. [SEP] “You’re just lucky that Dvorov isn’t my only contact. Come on, we’re heading out.” [SEP] He held the door for me and Amy when we reached the bottom of the stairs. [SEP] Walking outside, I was shocked to see that it was already dark. [SEP] “Night
column3: quickly here,” said Nepthys quietly as he came out behind me. [SEP] “Didn’t I warn you?” “Okay,” he said as we hit the street, “we’re going to see another friend of mine. First, though, we are getting you a hat. You look ridiculous with a shaved head.” [SEP] At a nearby stand, he grabbed the first hat that would cover my head and might pass back in real Boston. If he got your girl, she’s probably dead!” [SEP] I shook him off and squeezed between two dancing nymphs, getting almost to the edge of the dance floor. [SEP] Suddenly, Amy screamed. [SEP] I whirled around and threw up my arm just in time to knock Dvorov away. [SEP] His eyes were glowing red, and he had bared a set of fangs that could probably take my hand off. [SEP] The dancers near us tried to clear some space. [SEP] He shot back up, hardly touching the ground, and I kicked him back. [SEP] He jumped at my arm while I was still off-balance, and I felt the surge of adrenaline that
column3: right when your body realizes that it’s too late to save itself. [SEP] A heavy thing hit my arm with a thump and knocked me back against someone with rough paws who held me up. [SEP] On the floor was Dvorov’s head, separated from his body by several feet and a growing puddle of dark blood. [SEP] Nepthys stood over him with a blue sword in his hand. column1: After twenty minutes of that, our mutual contact will probably know it off by heart. [SEP] On a more serious note, we come to the matter of cost. [SEP] As your bank has often pointed out, the ongoing drive for greater efficiency

[SEP] Regrettably, but again following your example, I must also levy an establishment fee to cover the setting up of this new arrangement.

column1: re long and narrow and wider on the foothill side than on the craton side. [SEP] Punga Lake is superimposed over the structure of the Santa Elena uplift (Dumont and Garcia, 1991), which is interpreted as a crystalline horst surrounded by Paleozoic sedimentary strata (Laurent, 1985). [SEP] The NE elongation of the lake is parallel to a few of the structural features mentioned by Laurent (1985). [SEP] Both lakes are also parallel to the strike of normal faulting with a NNW–SSE extension in the upland border (Dumont et al., 1988). [SEP] As a result, the lakes are interpreted as the surface expression of tensional stress superimposed over reactivated basement structures due to the onset of Andean tectonics (Dumont and Garcia, 1991). [SEP] More precise morphological evidence of active tectonics
column3: from the Punga Lake. [SEP] According to testimony of old settlers and published travel journals (Stiglish, 1904) the area was covered by forest, that developed on a terrace before 1923. [SEP] Then the region began to subside. [SEP] The tree trunks of the drowned forest are still visible, now below 2 m of water during low water stages. [SEP] In this very flat area the water level rises about 2 m during floods, suggesting a minimum subsidence of 4 m over about 70 years. [SEP] A tectonic interpretation is favored because a local rise of base level cannot be involved. [SEP] Only a downward motion of the area where the lake is observed can explain the phenomenon. [SEP] These lakes are related to downdropped blocks that are related to a tensional system. [SEP] Terraces

column1: . [SEP] Cast iron replaces wrought iron and high-quality bricks, fired in the estate brickworks, back-up the limestone walls. [SEP] Equally novel are the elevators and telephones, electrical lighting, hot and cold running water, and forced air central heating. [SEP] There is no doubt that for Hunt, Biltmore is an up-to-the-minute modern building. [SEP] That is part of its style, too. [SEP] Like Hunt, Frank Gehry enlists novel materials in his buildings. [SEP] The Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, for example, is clad in titanium, previously used chiefly for building aircraft. [SEP] The metallic walls curve, twist, and turn. [SEP] One part of the building slides under an adjoining bridge; another emerges from a reflecting pool. [SEP] Bilbainos refer to the museum as the “artichoke,” which
column3: close to describing it, if you can imagine a gleaming, metallic artichoke more than two hundred feet high. [SEP] The seeming disorder—a chaotic collision of forms—has no architectural precedent. [SEP] This is not sculptural architecture, it is walk-in sculpture. [SEP] “The plan is the generator” preached Le Corbusier, but with Gehry, the plan is the result. [SEP] He appears to design from the outside in. [SEP] The building as a composition
